Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation2: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Story: It’s Sunday afternoon, and my phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend! Call us when you can.” I glance at the clock, guilt prickling at me. I haven’t called home in over a week, and I know my parents worry if I go too long without checking in. I type a quick reply, promising to call later, but my laptop screen pulls my attention back. There’s a project deadline looming—my part is due tonight, and if I don’t finish, my teammate can’t start her section tomorrow. The pressure is mounting; I can almost feel my colleague’s anxious anticipation through our group chat. I want to be the reliable teammate who never lets anyone down, but I also want to be the caring daughter who makes time for her family. My mind races, torn between dialing my parents and diving back into spreadsheets, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in from either side.
